"Conservative" and "liberal" are words we throw around which have political connotations. This is after all how we tend to view the outcome of cases-which political side "won" or "lost." "Law and order issues" like those in Heller, for example, can be very politicized, and so we call judges either "conservative" or "liberal" based upon how they rule on these law enforcement issues. 
 
 But to understand why Justice Scalia is the dominant ideological force on the court today you have to look beyond this shallow "conservative" or "liberal" label, because Scalia tells us that for him the Constitution is not a "conservative" v. "liberal" issue. For Scalia the question is not a political "what would Bush do" as opposed to "what would Obama do" so much as it is what he believes the Constitution requires-and in this sense he is very consistent. 
 
 And so if you look at Dickerson v. United States, 530 U.S. 428, 455 (2000) and Hudson v. Michigan, 547 U.S. 586, 586 (2006), for example, you find Scalia fitting the traditional "conservative" and "law and order" judge mould-ruling for law enforcement against the interest of the individual defendant-because each case dealt with judicially created rules limiting law enforcement actions which he believed the Constitution did not require.
 
 But Scalia has and will continue to violate the "conservative" political label when he believes the Constitution requires it. Take, for example, Crawford v. Washington, 541 U.S. 36, 67 (2004). In this case SCOTUS ruled against a judicially created rule that allowed the government to admit a "hearsay" statement against a defendant on the grounds that the statement had such a guarantee of reliability that there was no need to produce the actual witness. SCOTUS found this rule violated the 6th. Amendment right to confront and cross examine your accuser. "Liberal" justice Stevens, as expected, was in the majority in this case. What was unexpected by many, however, was that "conservative" justice Scalia wrote the majority opinion (and thereby joined forces with his perceived "liberal arch nemesis" justice Stevens.) But in reality Scalia merely reaffirms his view that the Constitution binds all branches of government-and that in this case the right to confront and cross examine your accusers cannot be set aside by a judicial rule: 
 
 The Constitution prescribes a procedure for determining the reliability of testimony in criminal trials, and we, no less than the state courts, lack authority to replace it with one of our own devising.
 
 And so you can see it is not what is good for "conservatives" or bad for "liberals," it is what he feels the Constitution demands. We saw it this year when Scalia joined forces yet again with Justice Stevens in Arizona v. Gant, 556 U.S. ___ 07542, II (2009), in which both justices agreed that the 4th. Amendment did not permit a "search incident to arrest" of a car after a defendant has been taken out of it and stuffed into a police cruiser. People who view Scalia only as a "conservative" could never have guessed that he would have joined with "liberal" justice Stevens on this issue. 
 
 And Scalia's "what does the constitution demand" view is consistent regardless of the political consequences. Two months ago Scalia issued the majority opinion of Melendez-Diaz v. Massachusetts, 557 U.S. ___ 07591, 12 (2009) (again dragging "liberal" Justice Stevens along with him in his wake). For decades we have proved drug cases by having a scientist who tests the drug submit an affidavit which says "its cocaine" or "its marijuana"-without having to call the scientist to testify about his findings. In Melendez-Diaz Scalia and Stevens both agree that this practice violates the Constitution's 6th. Amendment right to confront and cross examine witnesses giving evidence against you. Now in my state, for example, a mere handful of scientists each test thousands of drug samples every year, and the effect of forcing them to come to court for each case has created utter chaos for law enforcement's ability to prosecute drug offenders. But for Scalia it's not a question of what are the political or practical ramifications of a ruling. It's about what he feels the Constitution demands: 
 
 Respondent and the dissent may be right that there are other ways - and in some cases better ways - to challenge or verify the results of a forensic test.5 But the Constitution guarantees one way: confrontation. We do not have license to suspend the Confrontation Clause when a preferable trial strategy is available.
 
 Now before we go further bear in mind that District Of Columbia v. Heller, 554 U.S. ___ 07290 (2008) was a "crime control" and "law and order" case. Galileo suggests the following should have occurred when Heller arrived at SCOTUS' door step:
 
 
It probably would have been better if Scalia had said to himself when the case was brought before the court, "There certainly is no consensus about the meaning of the Second Amendment and I, as an amateur historian, am certainly not going to force my own personal views on others. I will let the people decide through their elected representatives how much gun control is necessary in their own communities." 

 
 I disagree. It is precisely the role of SCOTUS to interpret and apply the Constitution. You cannot ask SCOTUS to abandon its function and have the justices wring their hands in dismay because there is not a universal consensus as to how they should rule before they take up a case. It is not the duty of SCOTUS to wait for the legislature to reach a consensus decision about the Constitution and then merely act as a rubber stamp to ratify that consensus. Instead, I believe SCOTUS has the duty to enforce and defend the Constitution regardless of the political consequences-and I believe it did so in Heller: 
 
 We are aware of the problem of handgun violence in this country, and we take seriously the concerns raised by the many amici who believe that prohibition of handgun ownership is a solution. The Constitution leaves the District of Columbia a variety of tools for combating that problem, including some measures regulating handguns, see supra, at 54-55, and n. 26. But the enshrinement of constitutional rights necessarily takes certain policy choices off the table. These include the absolute prohibition of handguns held and used for self-defense in the home. Undoubtedly some think that the Second Amendment is outmoded in a society where our standing army is the pride of our Nation, where well-trained police forces provide personal security, and where gun violence is a serious problem. That is perhaps debatable, but what is not debatable is that it is not the role of this Court to pronounce the Second Amendment extinct.
 
 And it is most certainly not the role of a judge to pick and choose which parts of the Constitution he personally thinks are worth protecting today:
 
 We know of no other enumerated constitutional right whose core protection has been subjected to a freestanding "interest-balancing" approach. The very enumeration of the right takes out of the hands of government - even the [Slip Op. 63] Third Branch of Government - the power to decide on a case-by-case basis whether the right is really worth insisting upon. A constitutional guarantee subject to future judges' assessments of its usefulness is no constitutional guarantee at all. Constitutional rights are enshrined with the scope they were understood to have when the people adopted them, whether or not future legislatures or (yes) even future judges think that scope too broad. We would not apply an "interest-balancing" approach to the prohibition of a peaceful neo-Nazi march through Skokie. See National Socialist Party of America v. Skokie, 432 U.S. 43 (1977) (per curiam). The First Amendment contains the freedom-of-speech guarantee that the people ratified, which included exceptions for obscenity, libel, and disclosure of state secrets, but not for the expression of extremely unpopular and wrong-headed views. The Second Amendment is no different. Like the First, it is the very product of an interest-balancing by the people - which JUSTICE BREYER would now conduct for them anew. And whatever else it leaves to future evaluation, it surely elevates above all other interests the right of law-abiding, responsible citizens to use arms in defense of hearth and home.
 
 Now let me turn to Justice Stevens and his complaint that that 'a genuine judicial conservative' would not have inserted the Court into the 'political thicket' of the gun rights debate as Scalia had done." Apparently justice Stevens believes that only he should have the power to insert the Court into matters which have political import. Regardless of who inserts the Court into these issues, however, I believe that the justices should not abandon their principles to reach the outcome they desire-as I believe Stevens did.

In the history of SCOTUS case law there is no other example of a justice attempting such a ridiculous thing. It is little wonder that Scalia heaped such scorn on Stevens' attempt to use the militia clause as a shackle to limit the words "bear arms":
 
 A purposive qualifying phrase that contradicts the word or phrase it modifies is unknown this side of the looking glass (except, apparently, in some courses on Linguistics).

In that opinion, the three justices decide that the term "bear arms" can only mean to do so in a military context:
 
 The term "bear arms" is a familiar idiom; when used unadorned by any additional words, its meaning is "to serve as a soldier, do military service, fight.
 
 (of course, they already ignore that the term "bear arms" is in reality "adorned by additional words"-namely, "to keep and bear arms." But then again, who cares about having to use all the words when you have a linguistics professor at your disposal to parse them into what you want them to say?) 
 
 Justice Scalia, however, remembered when justices Ginsburg and Souter were with him on this issue previously. He remembered an earlier occasion when together they had adopted very different language to define the term "bear arms" in the 2nd. Amendment-language that placed the term well outside of a military-only context. That prior case was Muscarello v. United States, 524 U.S. 125 (1998), in which Ginsburg wrote a dissent joined by both Scalia and Souter. In Heller, Scalia gently chides the reversal of their previous position on the term "bear arms" by noting (of Ginsburg's opinion in Muscarallo):
 
 We think that JUSTICE GINSBURG accurately captured the natural meaning of "bear arms."
 
 This, in turn, led Stevens/Ginsburg/Souter to petulantly complain in Heller:
 
 The Court's repeated citation to the dissenting opinion in Muscarello v. United States, 524 U.S. 125 (1998), ante, at 10, 13, as illuminating the meaning of "bear arms," borders on the risible. At issue in Muscarello was the proper construction of the word "carries" in 18 U.S.C. § 924(c) (2000 ed. and Supp. V); the dissent in that case made passing reference to the Second Amendment only in the course of observing that both the Constitution and Black's Law Dictionary suggested that something more active than placement of a gun in a glove compartment might be meant by the phrase "'carries a firearm.'" 524 U.S., at 143.
 
 Now it is true that Muscarello didn't have anything to do with the 2nd. Amendment-it dealt with how to define the word "carry" in a firearm possession statute passed by Congress. But read for yourself Justice Ginsburg's dissent, as adopted by Souter and Scalia, and tell me whether what they said then can be squared with the "military only" definition of "bear arms" that Ginsburg and Souter chose to later adopted in Heller: 
 
 Unlike the Court, I do not think dictionaries,2 surveys of press reports,3 or the Bible4 tell us, dispositively, what "carries" [Page 143] means embedded in § 924(c)(1). On definitions, "carry" in legal formulations could mean, inter alia, transport, possess, have in stock, prolong (carry over), be infectious, or wear or bear on one's person.5 At issue here is not "carries" at large but "carries a firearm." The Court's computer search of newspapers is revealing in this light. Carrying guns in a car showed up as the meaning "perhaps more than one-third" of the time. Ante, at 129. One is left to wonder what meaning showed up some two-thirds of the time. Surely a most familiar meaning is, as the Constitution's Second Amendment ("keep and bear Arms") (emphasis added) and Black's Law Dictionary, at 214, indicate: "wear, bear, or carry . . . upon the person or in the clothing or in a pocket, for the purpose . . . of being armed and ready for offensive or defensive action in a case of conflict with another person." Muscarello v. United States, 524 U.S. 125, 142-143 (1998) JUSTICE GINSBURG, dissenting, with whom THE CHIEF JUSTICE, JUSTICE SCALIA, and JUSTICE SOUTER joined. (Note: the bold emphasis was by me.
